questions.text: The child has difficulty focusing on tasks for more than 5–10 minutes
The child often interrupts others or speaks out of turn
The child has difficulty waiting for their turn in group activities
The child appears restless or fidgets frequently during seated tasks
The child is easily distracted by external stimuli (noises, movement, objects)
The child struggles to express their thoughts clearly
The child has trouble remembering the names of letters, numbers, or common objects
The child mispronounces words frequently or has difficulty forming sentences
The child struggles to follow 2–3 step verbal instructions
The child has difficulty retelling a story or describing events in order
The child has difficulty recognizing letters, numbers, or symbols
The child struggles to identify which of two groups has more or fewer items
The child often confuses sequences (days of week, counting, or letter order)
The child takes longer than peers to solve simple puzzles or pattern tasks
The child has difficulty understanding cause-and-effect relationships in simple tasks
The child struggles with tasks requiring fine motor skills (cutting, drawing, holding pencil)
The child's handwriting or drawing is noticeably messy compared to peers
The child has difficulty copying shapes, letters, or numbers accurately
The child has trouble tying shoelaces or manipulating small fasteners
The child struggles to complete tasks requiring hand-eye coordination (e.g., stringing beads, placing pegs)
The child's handwriting is messy or inconsistent compared to peers
The child avoids tasks that require drawing, writing, or manipulating small objects
The child copies letters, numbers, or simple shapes inaccurately or slowly
The child has difficulty making eye contact or interacting socially with peers
The child struggles to understand or respond appropriately to others' emotions
The child initiates play with other children without prompting
The child responds appropriately when another child shares a toy or idea
The child struggles to join group activities even when invited
The child prefers solitary play most of the time
The child maintains friendships or shows interest in peers over time
The child follows rules in group settings consistently
The child can participate in structured activities without disrupting others
The child shifts attention smoothly between different tasks when asked
The child can cope with minor criticism without strong negative reactions
